I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan,  and  (ii)  proposed  administration  of  a  grant  to  be  provided  by  the  Global  Environment 
Facility  (GEF),  both  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Shaanxi  Weinan  Luyang 
Integrated  Saline  Land  Management  Project. 1  The 
report  also  describes  proposed 
administration of technical assistance (TA) to be provided by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund2 under 
the  Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility  for  the  Management  and  Protection  of  Wetlands  in 
Weinan City in Shaanxi Province, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under 
the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.3 
 
2. 
The  project  is  located  in  Luyanghu,  a  low-lying  waterlogged  area  35  kilometers  (km) 
north  of  Weinan  city,  Shaanxi  province.  The  project  will  support  the  Weinan  municipal 
government  (WMG)  in  reducing  flood  risk,  soil  salinity,  and  waterlogging  for  an  economic 
development zone and agricultural lands in the Luyanghu area, which will directly benefit rural 
communities in the area. The project will also support the WMG in finalizing and implementing a 
management  plan for  the  Luyanghu  National Wetland  Park  (LNWP),  in close  cooperation  with 
the 
local  communities,  which  will  ensure  wetland  conservation  while  creating  new 
nonagricultural livelihood opportunities through tourism and other activities.4  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Government  development  strategy.  In  2009,  the  State  Council  approved  the 
establishment  of  the  Guanzhong–Tianshui  Economic  Zone  (GTEZ),  one  of  three  economic 
development zones defined in the Eleventh Five-Year Plan for the western region.5  The GTEZ 
will  cover  79,800  square  kilometers  (km2)  in  selected  cities  of  Shaanxi  and  Gansu  provinces 
with construction planned from 2009 to 2020.6 By 2020 the gross domestic product output of the 
GTEZ  is  expected  to  reach  one-third  of  the  western  region.  The  municipal  government  of 
Weinan city, which is located in the east of Guanzhong Plain and part of the GTEZ, designated 
the Luyanghu area as one of the development areas in the GTEZ. The WMG has a long-term 
development  plan  (2007–2025)  for  the  Luyanghu  area  to  attract  high-technology  industrial 
investment,  promote  tourism,  and  create  job  opportunities.  In  December  2007,  the  WMG 
established the Weinan Luyanghu Modern Industry Development Zone Management Committee 
(WLMIDZMC)  to  coordinate  development  efforts,  and  the  Weinan  Luyang  Construction 
Development Company to be responsible for infrastructure improvement. 
 
Luyanghu  comprises  a  total  watershed  of  1,123  km2  across  Fuping  and  Pucheng 
4. 
counties.  It  is  a  national  poverty  area.  In  2012,  the  population  of  the  project  area  is 
approximately 113,000, mostly rural villagers; approximately 30% of rural households live below

CNY4,372,  one-third  lower  than  the  Shaanxi  provincial  average  and  roughly  a  quarter  of  the 
average annual income of urban residents in the same municipality. Agricultural productivity is 
low because of poor soil conditions and drainage problems. Local residents grow limited wheat 
and corn crops, with production only half of that in other areas of Weinan city. A small but active 
salt-harvesting and processing industry continues and needs to be preserved. 
 
5. 
Land  management. The decades-long poor environmental conditions of the Luyanghu 
area  are  mainly  due  to  long-term  problems  of  saline  soil,  high  groundwater  tables,  poor 
drainage systems, and subsequent flooding problems. The groundwater table is approximately 
0–3 meters below the surface. The salt and mineral content of groundwater and soil is now very 
high in certain areas, significantly reducing agricultural productivity.  In 1974, to reduce the salt 
content and improve agricultural productivity, the government established the Luoxi desalination 
drainage system, which comprises one main desalination drainage channel, four subcanals, and 
branch and secondary branch drainage channels. The system serves an area of approximately 
212  km2.  Due  to  insufficient  investment,  the  original  design  of  the  desalination  system  was  of 
poor quality, and lack of maintenance made the system ineffective to reduce soil salinity.  
 
6. 
The  WMG  envisages  a  balanced  approach  to  promoting  and  protecting  the  economic 
development  zone  (covering  approximately  15  km2),  while  improving  the  natural  environment 
and supporting rural livelihoods in the surrounding agricultural lands of approximately 186 km2. 
Specific interventions needed to ensure sustained economic growth include (i) rehabilitation of 
the Luoxi desalination drainage system to remove salts from the soil, (ii) improvement of flood 
storage capacity of Luyanghu area to reduce flood risks to local residents and the development 
zone,  and  (iii)  rehabilitation  and  conservation  of  the  remaining  wetland  environment.  The 
Shaanxi provincial government (SPG) initiated establishment of the LNWP and prepared a draft 
master plan, but no further activities have been carried out.  
 
Consistency  with  country  partnership  strategy.  The project supports ADB's country 
7. 
partnership  strategy  (CPS)  for  the  PRC, 7  which  is  based  on  the  pillars  of  Strategy  2020: 
inclusive growth, environmentally sustainable growth, and regional cooperation and integration. 
Natural resources and agriculture is a CPS priority sector. ADB provides lending and technical 
assistance  to  contribute  to  sound  land,  water,  and  natural  resources  management  that  also 
support rural livelihood improvement. In particular, ADB promotes innovative and demonstration 
projects where ADB can play a catalytic role in addressing poverty, rising income inequality, and 
widening regional  disparities. The  project  will  support  priorities  of the  PRC's Twelfth  Five-Year 
Plan, 2011–2015, particularly efforts to move to a greener and more inclusive development path.  
 
8. 
The  project  complements  ongoing  support  to  Shaanxi  province,  including  the  Shaanxi 
Qinling  Biodiversity  Conservation  and  Demonstration  Project,  and  the  Forestry  and  Ecological 
Restoration  Project  in  Three  Northwest  Provinces.8 These  projects  demonstrate  the  important 
role that  ADB  plays  to  introduce  innovative  and  good  practices  to  strengthen  sustainable  land 
management  and  biodiversity  conservation.  ADB  also  served  as  the  lead  GEF  agency  for  the 
PRC–GEF  Partnership  on  Land  Degradation  in  Dryland  Ecosystems,  which  ensured  that 
significant institutional capacity has been built in the central government, participating provinces, 
and  autonomous  regions,  including  Shaanxi  province.  Provincial  legal  and  policy  frameworks

C. 
 
Output  1:  Saline  soils  rehabilitated.  Output  1  will  reduce  soil  salinity  over 
10. 
approximately  212  km2  and  increase  productivity  and  climate  resilience  of  approximately  186 
km2 of agricultural land. It has two components: (i) rehabilitation of Luoxi drainage system, and 
(ii)  support  for  improving  resilience  to  climate  change  of  agro-ecosystems.  Under  the  first 
component, activities include (i) dredging and rehabilitating  approximately 46.9 km of the main 
desalination  drainage  channels;  (ii)  dredging  approximately  90.3  km  of  the  branch  and 
secondary  branch  drainage  channels;  (iii) rehabilitating  approximately  450  small  structures, 
including approximately 153 bridges, 69 culverts, 54 aqueducts, and 174 flow confluences; (iv) 
constructing  and  rehabilitating  approximately  35.6 km  of  rural  roads;  (v)  testing  at  least  10 
innovative  and  replicable  best  practices  for  rehabilitating  saline  soil  approximately  over  100 
hectares (ha), including discussions with farmers on implementation arrangements and support 
for  implementation  over  the  larger  project  area;  and  (vi)  providing  training  on  saline  land 
management to support expansion to a larger area. Under the second component, support will 
be  provided  to  (i)  reduce  the  vulnerability  of  local  communities  to  climate  change  through 
enhanced provision of regulating ecosystem services, such as water and temperature regulation 
and  soil  retention,  and  (ii)  local  farmers  to  improve  crop  productivity  in  the  approximately  186 
km2  of  agricultural  areas  where  drainage  will  be  improved.  Activities  to  support  improved 
resilience  to  climate  change  include  (i) testing  of  at  least  two  innovative  and  replicable  best 
practices for the establishment of shelter belts (covering approximately 2 ha); (ii) construction of 
approximately  130  ha  of  greenbelts;  and  (iii)  support  for  farmers  to  market  their  products  and 
increase alternative income generating livelihood. Suitable activities—particularly items (v) and 
(vi)  under  the  first  component,  and  item  (iii)  under  the  second  component—will  also  target 
households headed by women to ensure that they equally benefit from the project.  
 
Output  2:  Flood risk  management implemented.  Output 2 will improve flood storage 
11. 
capacity of Luyanghu area to reduce flood risks to local residents. It includes (i) construction of 
Tianlu lake (approximately 130 ha), connecting Tianjiao lake in the west, a middle main channel, 
and  a  central  main  channel;  and  (ii)  construction  of  approximately  18.6  km  of  dike  with  road 
around Tianlu lake. Combined with Tianjiao lake, the project will provide flood storage capacity 
of 5.4 million cubic meters to protect against flood events, with maximum capacity of 12.6 million 
cubic meters to protect against a 50-year flood event. The integrated and innovative approach 
combining flood risk management with drainage system rehabilitation and wetlands ecosystem 
conservation will contribute to reduced flood risk for the Luyanghu area.  
 
12. 
Output  3:  Wetland  ecosystem  conservation  established.  Output  3  has  two 
components:  (i)  support  for  LNWP  development;  and  (ii)  promotion  of  tourism,  livelihood,  and 
employment  opportunities  for  local  communities.  The  wetlands  conservation  will  reverse 
ecosystem  degradation  caused  by  agricultural  encroachment  and  other  pressures  associated 
with  the  increasing  population  within  the  project  area.  The  first  component  will  (i)  rehabilitate 
approximately  860  ha  of  degraded  wetlands;  (ii)  prepare  and  support  implementation  of  the 

3

LNWP  master  plan  for  approximately  1,070  ha;  (iii)  establish  a  wetland  management  training 
facility;  (iv)  test  at  least  two  innovative  and  replicable  best  practices  in  wetland  rehabilitation 
(covering  approximately  10  ha);  and  (v)  train  50  officials  on  wetland  environment  and 
management. The  second  component  will  support  the  development  of ecotourism focusing  on 
the  ecological  values  of  the  wetlands  and  the  cultural  heritage  of  salt  harvesting  in  the  area. 
Training on livelihood skills will be provided for approximately 1,000 villagers, at least 50% will 
be women, and be primarily targeted at people displaced due to land acquisition.  
 
Output  4:  Capacity  development  and  project  implementation  support  provided. 
13. 
Output  4  has  two  components:  (i)  institutional  strengthening,  and  (ii)  project  management 
support during project implementation. The first will support capacity development and training 
of WMG  and WLMIDZMC  staff  in  ADB  project  management  procedures,  technical  design  and 
implementation,  and  safeguard  supervision  and  monitoring.  The  introduction  of  12  GEF-
financed innovative best practices for sustainable land and wetland management, together with 
the  international  consulting  services,  will  significantly  strengthen  WMG  capacity.  The  second 
component  will  provide  overall  project  implementation  support  for  the WMG  and WLMIDZMC, 
including implementation of land acquisition and resettlement.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
The TA will support the WMG in establishing wetland management measures in at least 
18. 
one  site  in  and/or  near  the  project  area  to  support  similar  migratory  waterbird  habitats  in  the 
area. The impact will be improved management of wetlands for migratory waterbird populations 
in  Shaanxi  province.  The  outcome  will  be  strengthened  capacity  of  Weinan  municipality  to 
mitigate  impacts  on  migratory  waterbirds  and  their  habitats  in  Luyanghu  area.  The  TA  will 
contribute to the implementation of output 3 and the preparation of the project’s environmental 
monitoring  plan.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $450,000,  of  which  $350,000  equivalent  will  be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Multi-Donor  Trust  Fund 12  under  the  Water  Financing 
Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support 
in  the  form  of  remuneration  and  per  diem  of  counterpart  staff,  miscellaneous  administrative 
support, office accommodation, local transport, and other in-kind contributions. ADB will finance 
and  engage  three  consultants  to  support  the  WMG—international  (5  person-months)  and 
national  (10  person-months)—in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time) using the individual consultant selection method. The TA 
will be implemented from 1 July 2013 to 31 December 2014. The TA proceeds will be disbursed 
in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended 
from time to time). The TA is described in detail in the PAM. Equipment purchased under the TA 
will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from 
time to time) and transferred to the WMG upon TA completion. 
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
Due diligence assessed the project’s technical feasibility and sustainability. The WMG’s 
19. 
domestic feasibility  study  report  is technically  sound  and  provides  sufficient  information  on  the 
design  feasibility.  International  and  national  consulting  services  will  provide  the  necessary 
technical support to ensure that international best practices are integrated into the final detailed 
design, and are applied during construction and implementation. The design to rehabilitate the 
drainage system is consistent with the original layout of the 1974 system, but will correct design 
features that rendered the current system ineffective: the current gradients of the main channels 
are too low and no secondary branch channels or field ditches were provided. The flood control 
infrastructure is designed to protect against a 10-year flood event over 18,600 ha, and a 50-year 
flood  event  over  1,500  ha  of  the  industrial  and  commercial  development  zone.  The  wetland

Environmental benefits will be achieved through (i) designation and management of the 
LNWP, (ii) protection of natural wetland habitats, (iii) monitoring and management of migratory 
water  birds  and  habitats,  and  (iv)  improved  local  agency  capacity  for  wetland  management. 
Adverse  project  impacts  include  (i)  loss  of  110  ha  of  habitat  for  some  migratory  water-bird 
populations  due  to  construction  of  Tianlu  lake;  (ii)  risk  of  eutrophication  in  Tianlu  and Tianjiao 
lakes;  and  (iii)  standard  construction  impacts,  including  water,  soil,  air,  and  noise  pollution. 
Measures to address these include (i) develop and protect wetland habitats for migratory water 
birds  in  the  western  part  of  the  project  area,14 (ii)  construct  new  salt-pan  habitat  for  migratory 
water birds, (iii) incorporate additional wetland habitat in the LNWP, (iv) develop and implement 
a  nutrient  management  plan,  and  (v)  implement  standard  mitigation  and  monitoring  measures 
during  construction  and  operation.  The  EMP  will  be  revised  based  on  the  detailed  project 
design, if necessary.

29. 
To  mitigate  the  negative  impacts  of  economic  displacements,  the  resettlement  plan 
includes acceptable compensation standards and entitlements, external and internal monitoring, 
an  implementation  schedule,  and  budget.  The  grievance  redress  mechanism  for  involuntary 
resettlement will be combined with that of the EMP (para. 26). During project preparation, major 
efforts were undertaken to reduce permanent land acquisition from over 1,050 ha to the current 
number of 172 ha, to reduce the proportion of agricultural land from 50% to around 30%, and to 
improve  livelihood  restoration  measures  and  provide  replacement  land.  Temporary  land 
occupation  was  reduced  from  around  730  ha  to  below  480  ha,  needed  mainly  to  dispose 
temporarily of spoil from lake excavation and canal dredging. Total land acquisition costs were 
reduced  significantly  from  around  30%  to  around  6%  of  the  total  project  costs.  The  initially 
planned acquisition of significant areas of agricultural land and saltpans for the establishment of 
wetlands was averted by (i) revising the project scope and design; and (ii) excluding large areas 
initially planned for future development, and limiting land acquisition to land required strictly for 
project  use.  The  establishment  of  the  LNWP  under  management  by  the  State  Forestry 
Administration does not preclude land users from continuing their livelihood activities. According 
to the environmental assessments, the continuation of these activities will not have a negative 
impact on the wetland, and therefore no access or other livelihood restrictions are envisioned.
